tit.e: Kenbokkaishi (Embassy to Bokkai Dynasty from Japan)
tit.cmt: eliminated description in parenthesis since there are too many details described within the description written below

sen.j: 遣渤海使（けんぼっかいし）とは、日本が渤海 (国)に派遣した使節。
sen.e: Kenbokkaishi refers to an embassy sent to Bokkai (Bohai, kingdom in Manchura and North Korea, established after the fall of Goguryeo, Pohai, Balhae), and there is a record that, between 728 and 811, kenbokkaishi was dispatched 14 times (of which, one time was a dispatch of a Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China via Bokkai and there was also a dispatch of steermen).

Kenbokkaishi refers to an envoy sent to Bokkai (Balhae, a kingdom in Manchuria and North Korea, established after the fall of Goguryeo). It is recorded that between 728 and 811 the Kenbokkaishi was dispatched fourteen times (one time dispatched as a Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China via Bokkai, and one that was a dispatch of navigators).
sen.cmt: changed "embassy" to "envoy"; according to the English wiki article, "Bohai" is the Chinese word for "Balhae," and "Pohai" is a variation of "Bohai" so I changed the description; changed "14" to "fourteen"; changed "steermen" to "navigators" for "操舵手" since the meaning of "steermen" was ambiguous to me; Manchura→Manchuria
sen.e: Kenbokkaishi refers to an envoy sent to Bokkai (Balhae, a kingdom in Manchuria and North Korea, established after the fall of Goguryeo).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理。

sen.j: 728年から811年までの間に14回（うち1回は渤海経由の遣唐使。このほか操舵手等の派遣が1回。）の使節が記録に残っている。

sen.j: 『続日本紀』によると、720年（養老4年）渡嶋津軽津司諸鞍男を風俗視察のため靺鞨国に派遣したとある。
sen.e: According to "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), Mono no Kurao, who was a Watarishima Tsugaru no tsu no tsukasa (official), was sent to Makkatsu Province for surveys of local customs in 720.

According to "Shoku Nihongi" (an imperially commissioned Japanese history text), Mono no Kurao, a Watarishima Tsugaru no tsu no tsukasa (official), was dispatched in 720 to take surverys on the local customs in Makkatsu (Mohe (or Malgal, Mogher), a Tungusic people in ancient Manchuria) Province.
sen.cmt: changed description of "Shoku Nihongi," using the first sentence from the English wiki article; added description for Makkatsu from the English wiki article;
sen.e: According to "Shoku Nihongi" (an imperially commissioned Japanese history text), MORO no Kurao, a Watarishima Tsugaru no tsu no tsukasa (official), was dispatched in 720 to take surveys on the local customs in Makkatsu (Mohe (or Malgal, Mogher), a Tungusic people in ancient Manchuria) Province.
sen.cmt: surveysスペル訂正しました。MORO no Kuraoに訂正しました。

sen.j: この靺鞨国については、津田左右吉をはじめ水本浩典、熊田亮介、石井正敏などが、北海道北部の粛慎日本（あしはせ）を指すとしているが、鳥山喜一、酒寄雅志、森田悌、関口明などが渤海のことであるとしており定説はない。
sen.e: Sokichi TSUDA, Hironori MIZUMOTO, Ryosuke KUMATA, and Masatoshi ISHII argue that Makkatsu Province is Ashihase in Northern Hokkaido, while Kiichi TORIYAMA, Masashi SAKAYORI, Tei MORITA, and Akira SEKIGUCHI argue that it is Bokkai, but there has not been an established theory.

sen.e: There is some deliberation in Japan about Makkatasu Province. While Sokichi TSUDA, Hironori MIZUMOTO, Ryosuke KUMATA and Masatoshi ISHII argue that it is a province in Northern Hokkaido, Japan called Ashihase, Kiichi TORIYAMA, Masashi SAKAYORI, Tei MORITA and Akira SEKIGUCHI argue that it is Bokkai, but there is no established theory.

sen.j: 後説によると、720年の遣使が契機となり渤海の渤海使が実現したことになるが、反論もある。
sen.e: According to the latter theory, Bokkaishi (embassy to Japan from the Bokkai Dynasty) was triggered by the Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China in 720, but there has been a theory against it, too.
According to the latter theory, Bokkaishi (an envoy from Bokkai to Japan) was triggered by the Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China in 720, but this has been refuted as well.

sen.j: 698年に大祚栄により建国された渤海 (国)であるが、大武芸の時代になると唐や新羅と外交的に対立するようになった。
sen.e: Bokkai was established by Jo-yeong DAE in 698 and it started to have conflicts with the Tang Dynasty and Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) in the Bugei DAI period.
sen.cmt: 大祚栄 「Jo-young DAE」とも表記するようです。一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Bokkai was founded as a nation by Dae Joyeong in 698. As it became the Dai Bugei (King Mu) period, the kingdom began having conflicts with the Tang Dynasty and Shiragi (Silla, an ancient Korean kingdom).
sen.cmt: added (Balhae), (King Mu) and (Silla) since the wiki articles in English use these spellings; changed "established" to "founded as a nation" as a translation of "建国"; "Jo-yeong DAE" is written as "Dae Joyeong" in its own wikipedia article so I changed it for consistency; split into two sentences and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Bokkai was founded as a nation by Dae Joyeong in 698, as it became the Dai Bugei (King Mu) period, the kingdom began having conflicts with the Tang Dynasty and Shiragi (Silla, an ancient Korean kingdom).
sen.cmt: コンマを補足し、一文にしました。

sen.j: これらの勢力を牽制する目的で日本への遣使が計画された。
sen.e: Dispatch of an embassy to Japan was planned for the purpose of overcoming these conflicting forces.

sen.e: The kingdom made a plan to dispatch an envoy to Japan with the purpose of restraining these powers.

sen.e: This dispatch of the embassy was basically for establishing a military alliance.

sen.j: また日本側も渤海が天皇の徳化により来朝したと捉えた。
sen.e: In Japan, it was understood that Bokkai dispatched an embassy because they were impressed with the Japanese Emperor's virtue, understood that the dispatch meant revitalization of Goguryeo which was a predecessor of Bokkai, treated the embassy extremely well, and dispatched Kenbokkaishi early the next year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Japan's perception on the envoy dispatched from Bokkai was that they visited Japan because they were impressed by the virtue of the Japanese Emperor. Japan understood that the envoy was dispatched in order to revitalize Goguryeo, the predecessor of Bokkai, treating the envoy extremely well and dispatching Kenbokkaishi early the following year.
sen.cmt: split into two sentences and fixed grammar to read more smoothly

sen.j: 759年（天平宝字3年）には藤原仲麻呂が渤海の要請によるとも言われるが軍船394隻、兵士4万700人を動員する本格的な新羅遠征計画を立てた。
sen.e: In 759, supposedly due to the request of Bokkai, FUJIWARA no Nakamaro created a full-scale plan to make an expedition to Shiragi, involving 394 military vessels and 40,700 soldiers.

sen.j: 大欽茂が唐との融和を図る時代になると軍事的な意味合いは薄れ、専ら文化交流と経済活動を中心とした使節へとその性格を変化させていった。
sen.e: When Kinmo DAI reconciled with the Tang Dynasty, embassy dispatch lost its military meaning and was executed for the purpose of cultural exchange and economic activities.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When Kinmo DAI reconciled with the Tang Dynasty, envoys no longer implied military activities and were carried out for the sole purpose of cultural exchange and economic activities.
sen.cmt: added "sole" for "専ら"; fixed grammar to read more clearly
sen.e: When Kinmo DAI reconciled with the Tang Dynasty, envoys no longer implied military activities and were carried out for the sole purpose of cultural exchange and economic activities.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: この交流は朝貢貿易の形態を取ったため、渤海からの貢物に対して、日本側では数倍の回賜でもって応える義務が生じた。
sen.e: The exchange was in the from of a tribute trade; therefore, after receiving tributes from Bokkai, Japan had to send return gifts that valued a few times more than the tribute from Bokkai.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Due to the exchanges being in the form of a tribute trade, Japan was obligated to send return gifts of several times more value after receiving tributes from Bokkai.

sen.e: Due to the exchanges being in the form of a tribute trade, Japan was obligated to send return gifts of several times more value after receiving tributes from Bokkai.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.e: While this was beneficial to Bokkai, it pressured Japanese finances.

sen.j: そのため、使節供応と回賜のための経費が無視できない規模になった後は、使節来朝に制限を加え、日本側からの遣使は中断した。
sen.e: For this reason, when expenses for treating embassies and preparing return gifts became significant, the Japanese government controlled embassy visits and terminated embassy dispatch from Japan.

This led to the Japanese government adding a limit to envoy visits to Japan and discontinuing the dispatch of envoys when the expenses for treating them and preparing return gifts could no longer be ignored.

sen.j: 遣渤海使一行（『延喜式』大蔵省式による） 大使、判官、録事、訳語、主神、医師、陰陽師、史生、船師、射手、卜部、雑使、船工、柂師、傔人、挟杪、水手。
sen.e: Kenbokkai members (according to "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) by Okura-sho shiki): ambassador, hangan (inspector (third highest of the four administrative ranks of the ritsuryo period), rokuji (clerk), osa (translator), shushin (ritual official of dazaifu under the ritsuryo system, governmental office with jurisdiction over Kyushu, Iki and Tsushima), doctor, ommyoji (master of yin yang), shisho (a person handling miscellaneous duties regarding documents), funashi, ite (archer), urabe (fortune teller serving Jingikan, the Department of Worship under the ritsuryo system), tsukahibito, boat-builder, steerman, kenjin (follower), kajitori, and kako (sailor).
